author: ladiesman velasco

text: Makes me imagine walking into a small rusty brown hut, from which all of my family stand huddled around a smokey black furnace. The warmth brushes against my face and embraces my cheeks. The aroma of burning hay delights my senses; an aroma with history and a past, like the inside of an old book. I sit before the furnace, staring deeply into the fire. Fatigue from a day of preventing the reign of lost souls suddenly captures me, and the roaring fire begins to blur, fading slowly into darkness.
author: Gabriel Easterby

author: Tommy Efreeti

text:
If a composer doesn't make good music anymore than THEY are not good anymore. The opposite is also true.
Anyways, my point is that why criticize the bad stuff when you'll only ever listen to it one time. The Beatles are great despite the mediocre pop that they started out with.
author: TargetHippo

text:
David Wise's most praised tracks consisted of in the 90s. Most of the works I refer to being not his best are actually from more GBA and beyond.
Even if that was reversed though I'd still take into account the old stuff seeing as many of these composer's best works have been from the past. By said logic, I should consider them bad because their quality has lackened over the years? I'm gonna take the good with the bad, and not single out any one type and ignore the other.
author: Arc13

text: I was wondering if you have released any tracks from the Professor Layton series, I looked on your channel and I couldn't find any
author: GingaVitus

text:
A composer should be praised for the amount of good songs they have. For example, If one person has 15 good songs, and another person has 17 equally good songs, then that composer is better.
Also, you have to take the time period into consideration. Yeah, a composer may have some bad songs, but if they're from 10 years ago, and they have since improved dramatically then it isn't really a song written by the CURRENT them and should no longer be acknowledged at all.
author: TargetHippo

text: That's not too fair. What if a composer has one soundtrack, greatest ever, but then they also made all of the worst soundtracks of all time? 1/11 would not make them the best, even if that one is insanely good. Not to say David Wise has a ton of bad on his credits, but to ignore the less than good is becoming a mindless fanboy. It's normal to like some stuff and dislike others. Yasunori Mitsuda is my favorite but I'll admit he has some crap on his resume.
author: Arc13

text: You can just ignore the bad stuff though.
author: TargetHippo

text: Oh no, number has nothing to do with(Naruke has a rather small list of games under her belt). It's more that while his more famous works are brilliant, he also has games like "It's Mr. Pants!" where the soundtracks are...less than stellar...
author: Arc13

text: Yeah, I guess. Maybe if he composed for more games.
author: TargetHippo

text: I've liked most of the animes I've watched but I'm no expert. I can get very addicted to them once I start. I usually have a soft spot for animes full of super powers and battles (DBZ being my childhood anime), but I do like other types as well (loved Welcome to the NHK, Death Note, etc.). Usually have some great music too, which is why (+ colors) I went from reading mangas to watching animes. But yeah, I don't watch them that much.
